title: Recognizing FOMO
content: FOMO (Fear of Missing Out) is one of the most powerful psychological forces in investing. It makes us buy at the worst times - when prices are already high and everyone is excited.
example: You see a stock up 50% this week. Twitter is buzzing. Your friend just made money on it. You feel the urge to buy NOW before it goes higher. This is FOMO.
key_takeaway: When everyone is excited, that's often when smart money is selling. The time to buy was before the excitement.

title: The FOMO Test
content: Before any trade, ask yourself: 'Would I make this same decision if no one else was talking about this?' If the answer is no, you might be experiencing FOMO.
example: A crypto is trending on social media. Apply the FOMO test: Without the social buzz, does this investment make sense based on fundamentals alone?
key_takeaway: Good investments should make sense in isolation, not just because others are doing it.

title: The Power of Waiting
content: The first 30 seconds of any investment decision are the most dangerous. Your brain hasn't processed the information - it's just reacting to stimuli.
example: Breaking news hits. Your instinct says 'ACT NOW!' But the best traders wait. They gather information, assess the situation, and then decide.
key_takeaway: Speed is rarely an advantage in investing. The market will still be there in 30 seconds.

title: Decision Cooling Periods
content: Professional traders often impose mandatory waiting periods before executing trades. This prevents emotional decisions disguised as urgent opportunities.
example: Rule: 'I will not make any trade within 60 seconds of seeing news or price movement.' This simple rule prevents most impulsive mistakes.
key_takeaway: Build in deliberate delays to your decision process. What feels urgent rarely is.

title: Understanding Loss Aversion
content: Studies show losses feel roughly twice as painful as equivalent gains feel good. This asymmetry causes us to make poor decisions to avoid the pain of losing.
example: A stock you own drops 10%. You feel terrible and want to sell to 'stop the bleeding.' But you wouldn't feel equally excited about a 10% gain.
key_takeaway: Recognize that your emotional response to losses is exaggerated. This awareness alone helps make better decisions.

title: Losses Are Part of Investing
content: Even the best investors are wrong 40-45% of the time. The goal isn't to never lose - it's to have your wins be bigger than your losses over time.
example: A trader wins 4 trades (+$100 each = +$400) and loses 6 trades (-$50 each = -$300). Net: +$100. More losses than wins, still profitable.
key_takeaway: Focus on the math of your overall strategy, not on avoiding every individual loss.

title: Position Sizing Basics
content: The size of your position matters more than the direction. A small position in a big winner is better than a big position in a small loser that wipes you out.
example: Never risk more than 5% of your capital on a single trade. If you have $10,000, no single position should risk more than $500.
key_takeaway: Protect your capital above all else. You can't recover from zero.

title: The 1% Rule
content: Professional traders often limit their risk to 1% of total capital per trade. This ensures survival through inevitable losing streaks.
example: With $10,000, risk maximum $100 per trade. If you hit 10 losses in a row (rare but possible), you've only lost 10% of your capital.
key_takeaway: Survival is the priority. Small, consistent risks allow you to stay in the game long enough to learn.

title: Information Before Action
content: Before any decision, identify at least 3 pieces of information you should check. News, price trends, and sentiment are a good starting trio.
example: Before buying: What's the recent news? Is the price trend up, down, or sideways? What's the general market sentiment?
key_takeaway: Create a mental checklist. Don't act until you've checked all boxes.

title: Seek Disconfirming Evidence
content: We naturally seek information that confirms our existing beliefs. Fight this by actively looking for reasons your trade idea might be wrong.
example: You're bullish on a stock. Force yourself to find 3 reasons it might go down. If you can't find any, you haven't looked hard enough.
key_takeaway: The best analysis actively seeks to prove itself wrong.

title: Emotions as Information
content: Feeling excited? That might mean you're about to make an impulsive decision. Feeling scared? That might mean there's real risk to consider - or opportunity.
example: Notice: 'I'm feeling excited about this trade.' Then ask: 'Is this excitement based on analysis or hype?'
key_takeaway: Don't suppress emotions - use them as data. Strong feelings often signal something important.

title: The Physical Reset
content: When emotions run high, physical actions can break the pattern. Stand up, take a breath, look away from the screen for 10 seconds.
example: You just saw your position drop 15% in seconds. Instead of panic-selling, stand up, walk to the window, take 3 deep breaths, then return.
key_takeaway: Physical movement interrupts emotional spirals and engages the rational brain.

title: The Crowd Is Often Wrong
content: By the time everyone is talking about an investment, the easy money has usually been made. Mass attention often marks tops, not beginnings.
example: Bitcoin in late 2017: Everyone was talking about it. Your taxi driver had some. That was near the top, not the bottom.
key_takeaway: Be suspicious of investments that 'everyone' is excited about.

title: Influencers Aren't Advisors
content: Social media influencers often have hidden incentives. They may be paid to promote, or they bought earlier and need you to buy so they can sell.
example: A famous person tweets about a stock. Ask: 'When did they buy? Are they being paid? What happens to them if I lose money?'
key_takeaway: Always ask about incentives. Someone promoting an investment might not have your interests at heart.

title: Confidence vs Overconfidence
content: Confidence based on analysis is healthy. Confidence based on recent success or 'feeling it' is dangerous. Learn to tell the difference.
example: After 3 winning trades: 'I'm getting good at this!' Reality: 3 trades is statistically meaningless. You might have just been lucky.
key_takeaway: True confidence comes from process, not results. A good process will be confident even after losses.

title: The Pre-Mortem
content: Before making a trade, imagine it failed badly. Ask: 'If I lose 30% on this, what would I say went wrong?' If you can't answer, reconsider.
example: I'm about to buy NEWCO. Pre-mortem: 'If this fails, it would be because I didn't understand their business model or the market was overheated.'
key_takeaway: Imagining failure before it happens helps identify risks you might be ignoring.
